metadata.titleEn: Glacier coverage data  on the Tibetan Plateau  in 1970s (TPG1976, Version 1.0)
metadata.description: The Tibetan Plateau Glacial Data -TPG1976 is a glacial coverage data on the Tibetan Plateau in the 1970s. It was generated by manual interpretation from Landsat MSS multispectral image data. The temporal coverage was mainly from 1972 to 1979 by 60 m spatial resolution. It involved 205 scenes of Landsat MSS/TM. There were 189 scenes（92% coverage on TP）in 1972-79，including 116 scenes in 1976/77 (61% of all the collected satellite data).As high quality of MSS data is not accessible due to cloud and snow effects in the South-east Tibetan Plateau, earlier Landsat TM data was collected for usage, including 14 scenes of 1980s（1981,1986-89,which covers 6.5% of TP） and 2 scenes in 1994（by 1.5% coverage on TP）.Among all satellite data，77% was collected in winter with the minimum effects of cloud and seasonal snow. The most frequent year in this period was defined as the reference year for the mosaic image: i.e. 1976. Glacier outlines were digitized on-screen manually from the 1976 image mosaic, relying on false-colour image composites (MSS: red, green and blue (RGB) represented by bands 321; TM: RGB by bands 543), which allowed us to distinguish ice/snow from cloud. Debris-free ice was distinguished from the debris and debris-covered ice by its higher reflectance. Debris-covered ice was not delineated in this data. The delineated glacier outlines were compared with band-ratio results, and validated by overlapping them onto Google Earth imagery, SRTM DEM, topographic maps and corresponding satellite images. For areas with mountain shadows and snow cover, they were verified by different methods using data from different seasons. For glaciers in deep shadow, Google EarthTM imagery from different dates was used as the reference for manual delineation. Steep slopes or headwalls were also excluded in the TPG1976. Areas that appeared in any of these sources to have the characteristics of exposed ground/basement/bed rock were manually delineated as non-glacier, and were also cross-checked with CGI-1 and CGI-2. Steep hanging glaciers were included in TPG1976 if they were identifiable on images in all three epochs (i.e. TPG1976, TPG2001, and TPG2013). The accuracy of manual digitization was controlled within one half-pixel. All glacier areas were calculated on the WGS84 spheroid in an Albers equal-area map projection centred at (95°E, 30°N) with standard parallels at 15°N and 65°N. Our results showed that the relative deviation of manual interpretation was less than 6.4% due to the 60 m spatial resolution images.
metadata.instructions:
The name of the data file is 1976TPG.

background: Nearly all mountain glaciers have been melting rapidly in recent decades (Gardner and others, 2013; Zemp and others, 2015) and this has been documented, especially in High Mountain Asia (HMA hereafter), in surveys of the whole (Li and others, 2008; Cogley, 2016) or large parts (Bolch and others, 2012; Yao and others, 2012) of the region as well as in basin-scale and single-glacier studies (Fujita and Nuimura, 2011; Wang and others, 2013; Yang and others, 2013). As reported in these earlier studies, most HMA glaciers showed obvious shrinkage (area loss) and thinning (implying mass loss) except in the west, for example in the Karakoram (Gardelle and others, 2012) and western Kunlun (Neckel and others, 2014; Kääb and others, 2015; Ke and others, 2015). However, due to strong spatiotemporal differences of climate variability and topographic effects, the magnitudes of glacier shrinkage have varied in space and time. The TP, defined by outlines from Zhang and others (2014), can be divided into two categories of hydrological unit, the outlines and basin codes of which we take from Shi and others (2008). Generally, meltwater from glaciers in IB flows into inland depressions, while those in EC flow into the ocean and so contribute more directly to sea-level rise. Climatically, the Indian monsoon dominates in the southeastern TP in summer (e.g. in 5O, 5N, 5L), with some effects from the East Asian monsoon in the east (e.g. in 5Y4, 5J, 5K). The westerlies are dominant in winter, especially in the western TP (e.g. 5Y6, 5Z4, 5Z3). Regions in the interior TP, such as 5Z1, 5Z2, 5Z5, 5Z6 and 5Y5 are less influenced both by the summer monsoon and the westerlies (Yao and others, 2012).
research objective: In this study, we present debris-free glacier area changes and their spatial heterogeneity at the plateau scale from the 1970s to 2013 based on three mosaic Landsat images, i.e. in the 1970s (TPG1970s), TPG2001 and TPG2013. Another purpose of the study is to enrich the available collection of glacier inventories in HMA, by presenting a detailed comparison of TPG datasets with previous glacier inventories.
challenges: We were unable to remove debris-covered areas from the GAMDAM inventory (GGI) (Nuimura and others, 2015), which includes debris cover but does not distinguish it from debris-free ice. Obviously snow and clouds could have affected glacier delineation, especially in southeastern Tibet where cloudy days are rather frequent in every season. Nor is it likely that the area differences are due to different treatment of debris cover, which is omitted in TGP2001 and included in GAMDAM.
methods: Glacier outlines (TPG1976, TPG2001 and TPG2013) were digitized manually with guidance from the SRTM DEM v4.1 and Google Earth imagery. To achieve complete multi-temporal coverage in a reasonable time, only debris-free ice was delineated. Time series of Landsat scenes were processed with Standard Terrain Correction (Level 1T), which provided systematic radiometric and geometric accuracy by incorporating ground control points while employing SRTM DEM for topographic accuracy. High-quality images with minimal cloud and snow coverage were selected for the delineation of glaciers. Glacier outlines were digitized on-screen manually from the three image mosaics, relying on false-colour image composites (MSS: red, green and blue (RGB) represented by bands 321; TM/ETM+: RGB by bands 543, OLI: RGB by bands 654), which allowed us to distinguish ice and snow from cloud. The manual delineation was carried out by three operators over a period of 6 years. The delineated glacier outlines were validated and edited by different operators at least three times by overlaying them onto Google Earth imagery, DEMs, topographic maps and corresponding satellite images by another two glacier researchers with field survey experience.
dataset: Glacier area on the plateau decreased from 44 366 ± 2827 km2 (1.7% of the study area) in the 1970s to 42 210 ± 1621 km2 in 2001 and 41 137 ± 1616 km2 in 2013.
findings: The comparative analysis of three mosaics shows that glacier area loss across the entire Tibetan Plateau is unequivocal. The glaciers in the M1970-76 subset showed shrinkage at−0.19% a−1 during 1976– 2001 and −0.20% a−1 during 2001– 13. Glaciers in the M1970-88 subset shrank at −0.34% a−1 during 1988 – 2013, and in the M1970-94 subset at −0.42% a−1 during 1994– 2013. The most dramatic glacier shrinkage occurred in the Mekong basin (region 5L) in the southeast, with change rates for M1970s-76 glaciers of −0.43% a−1 during 1976 – 2013 (−0.31% a−1 during 1976– 2001 and −0.73% a−1 during 2001– 13). Glaciers in the western and northern Tibetan Plateau changed at the slowest rates: −0.12% a−1 in 5Y6, −0.14% a−1 in 5Z1, −0.17% a−1 in 5Y5 and −0.17% a−1 in 5Z5 from 1976 to 2013. Overall, glaciers in externally drained catchments showed more dramatic shrinkage than those in the internally drained catchments. This shows a spatial gradient across the plateau of glacier shrinkage rate, decreasing from the southeast to the north and the west.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced during glacier data collection in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Example.Answer: A significant challenge in glacier data collection is the presence of cloud cover and seasonal snow, particularly in southeastern Tibet. This can impede the accurate delineation of glaciers in satellite imagery, requiring careful selection of high-quality images and sometimes relying on the earliest available data of sufficient quality.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of how data accuracy is controlled when digitizing glacier outlines from satellite imagery?
Example.Answer: Data accuracy is controlled by ensuring the digitization of glacier boundaries is within half a pixel (30m) precision. The manual delineation process is validated by multiple operators using high-resolution Google Earth imagery and DEMs, ensuring congruence with topographic maps and field-verified satellite images. The final dataset aims for a comprehensive error margin of about 6.4%, with maximum errors analyzed and controlled in typical areas.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of glacier area delineation methods using remote sensing data?
Feature Specification.Answer: manual digitization, guided by SRTM DEM and Google Earth imagery, false-color image composites from Landsat scenes, high-quality images with minimal cloud and snow coverage, systematic radiometric and geometric correction, validated by overlaying onto various imagery and DEMs, checked by multiple operators for precision

Feature Specification.Question: What factors contribute to the spatial heterogeneity observed in glacier area changes?
Feature Specification.Answer: climate variability, topographic effects, hydrological units, influence of Indian and East Asian monsoons, westerlies

Definition.Question: What does 'manual digitization' mean in the context of glacier data collection?
Definition.Answer: Manual digitization in glacier data collection refers to the process where glacier outlines are digitized on-screen manually from image mosaics. This is done by operators who rely on false-colour image composites to distinguish ice and snow from clouds, ensuring accurate delineation of debris-free glacier areas.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used in extracting glacier outlines from Landsat imagery compare to traditional field-based survey methods in terms of precision and challenges?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection methods using Landsat imagery involve manual digitization with guidance from SRTM DEM and Google Earth imagery, ensuring systematic radiometric and geometric accuracy. Challenges include removing debris-covered areas and dealing with cloud and snow coverage. This method offers a broad spatial and temporal coverage, unlike traditional field-based surveys which might provide higher precision locally but lack the expansive coverage and face practical challenges in remote areas like the Tibetan Plateau.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences and similarities in the processing techniques of satellite imagery for glacier analysis between the 1970s and the more recent datasets?
Comparison.Answer: The processing of satellite imagery for glacier analysis in the 1970s involved the use of Landsat MSS/TM data corrected and mosaicked into false-color composites, with manual interpretation facilitated by SRTM DEM and Google Earth imagery. Recent datasets likely continue to use advanced processing techniques like Standard Terrain Correction and multi-temporal image mosaics, maintaining the fundamental approach of manual digitization but potentially benefiting from improved image resolutions and processing technologies.

Interpretation.Question: What can the patterns of glacier shrinkage across different regions tell us about the influence of local climatic conditions on glacier dynamics?
Interpretation.Answer: The patterns of glacier shrinkage reveal that there are strong spatiotemporal differences influenced by local climatic conditions. For instance, glaciers in the southeastern Tibetan Plateau, dominated by the Indian monsoon, show more dramatic shrinkage compared to other regions. This indicates that local climate factors, like monsoons, significantly impact glacier dynamics and cause variations in shrinkage rates across the plateau.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise from using Landsat imagery for glacier delineation, and how can these be mitigated in data collection?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in using Landsat imagery for glacier delineation include the presence of snow and clouds, which can obscure glacier boundaries, particularly in frequently cloudy areas like southeastern Tibet. To mitigate these challenges, high-quality images with minimal cloud and snow coverage are selected, and the use of false-color composites aids in distinguishing ice from clouds. Additionally, the integration of other data sources, such as SRTM DEM and Google Earth, helps in refining the glacier delineation process.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in distinguishing debris-free ice from debris-covered areas in glacier datasets, and how might these challenges impact data accuracy?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in distinguishing debris-free ice from debris-covered areas can arise from snow and cloud cover, especially in regions like southeastern Tibet where cloudy days are frequent. These conditions may affect glacier delineation accuracy, as debris-covered areas are not clearly differentiated in some inventories, potentially leading to discrepancies in glacier area measurements.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might there be discrepancies in glacier boundary digitalization accuracy, and what factors contribute to these potential errors?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Discrepancies in glacier boundary digitalization accuracy might result from the manual delineation process, which is subject to human interpretation and may vary between operators. Factors such as image quality, cloud cover, seasonal snow, and the presence of non-glacial features like bare rocks can contribute to these potential errors, despite using high-quality images and multiple validation steps.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on data accuracy when manually digitizing glacier outlines using various remote sensing data sources?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Manual digitization of glacier outlines using various remote sensing data sources can lead to higher data accuracy due to the combination of different datasets, expert knowledge, and multi-method approaches. However, challenges such as cloud cover and debris-covered areas may still affect the delineation process, particularly in regions like southeastern Tibet with frequent cloudy conditions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How could the inclusion or exclusion of debris-covered glacier areas affect the outcomes of glacier inventory datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Excluding debris-covered glacier areas from datasets can result in more precise measurements of debris-free glacier areas, as debris can obscure glacier boundaries. However, this may also lead to discrepancies when comparing datasets that include debris-covered areas, as seen with the GAMDAM inventory, potentially affecting overall assessments of glacier area changes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary goals of collecting glacier data using Landsat imagery on the Tibetan Plateau from the 1970s to 2013?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goals are to present debris-free glacier area changes and their spatial heterogeneity at the plateau scale over multiple decades and to enhance the available collection of glacier inventories in High Mountain Asia by providing detailed comparisons with previous glacier inventories.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are necessary to ensure accurate delineation of glacier outlines using Landsat imagery?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Glacier outlines are digitized manually with guidance from the SRTM DEM v4.1 and Google Earth imagery. High-quality images with minimal cloud and snow coverage are selected for delineation. False-color image composites are used to distinguish ice and snow from clouds. Manual delineation is carried out by multiple operators, and outlines are validated and edited by overlaying them onto various imagery and maps, ensuring accuracy through multiple reviews.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges are commonly encountered in removing debris-covered areas in glacier datasets, and how can these be addressed procedurally?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges in removing debris-covered areas include the inability to distinguish debris cover from debris-free ice in some inventories. Procedurally, these challenges can be addressed by using false-color composites to differentiate between ice and debris, employing DEM data for topographic accuracy, and manually digitizing outlines to exclude debris-covered areas. Consistent validation and cross-referencing with multiple data sources can help mitigate these challenges.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the extraction of accurate glacier boundaries in high-altitude regions using satellite imagery?
Enablement.Answer: The extraction of accurate glacier boundaries can be enabled by using methods such as manual digitization of glacier outlines from high-quality Landsat satellite imagery, which involves using false-color image composites and guidance from SRTM DEM and Google Earth imagery. This approach includes multi-operator validation and editing to ensure precision, and it accounts for systematic radiometric and geometric accuracy by incorporating ground control points.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or technologies enable the reduction of errors in glacier area measurement from satellite data?
Enablement.Answer: The reduction of errors in glacier area measurement from satellite data is enabled by employing high-resolution imagery, manual delineation with expert validation, and using a combination of data sources such as different Landsat images and DEMs. By ensuring that the digitization precision is controlled within half a pixel (30m), and by utilizing methods to eliminate the effects of clouds, snow, and non-glacier areas, the accuracy of the measurements is significantly improved.

Expectation.Question: Why might the integration of multiple data sources and expert knowledge be expected to produce more accurate glacier data, despite potential methodological complexities?
Expectation.Answer: By integrating multiple data sources such as SRTM DEM and Google Earth imagery, along with expert knowledge and manual interpretation, researchers can cross-validate and refine glacier boundaries, reducing errors from a single data source or method. This comprehensive approach allows for the correction of potential inaccuracies and the consideration of local topographic effects, leading to more reliable glacier data.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the implications of the reported 6.4% overall data error on research into glacier changes on the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The reported 6.4% overall data error implies that while the dataset provides a reliable basis for understanding glacier changes on the Tibetan Plateau, there is room for improvement in data precision. This error margin highlights the potential influence of data inaccuracies on the findings and suggests that future research could benefit from enhanced methodologies or datasets that further reduce uncertainty, potentially through more advanced sensors or improved processing techniques.

Assertion.Answer: To achieve accurate differentiation, the data collection method involves manual digitization of glacier outlines with guidance from SRTM DEM v4.1 and Google Earth imagery. High-quality images with minimal cloud and snow coverage are selected, and false-color image composites are used to distinguish ice from debris-covered areas.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced when delineating glacier boundaries using satellite imagery.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include the inability to remove debris-covered areas from inventories like GAMDAM, as well as potential effects of snow and clouds on glacier delineation, particularly in regions with frequent cloudy days. These factors can complicate the accurate mapping of glacier boundaries.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how data quality control measures ensure the precision of glacier boundary digitization.
Assertion.Answer: Data quality control measures ensure precision by keeping the glacier boundary digitization accuracy within half a pixel (30m). The process involves manual validation, editing, and comparison with various data sources, including Google Earth imagery and topographic maps, to minimize errors.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data processing techniques used for extracting glacier outlines from Landsat MSS/TM satellite data.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data processing techniques for extracting glacier outlines involve using Landsat MSS/TM satellite data to create false-color composite images (MSS, RGB:321; TM, RGB:543). Manual visual interpretation is employed, supported by various band ratio methods and combined with SRTM DEM V4.1 data and Google Earth imagery from different seasons of the same year. This process helps to eliminate the effects of mountain shadows and seasonal snow. Non-glacier areas such as steep cliffs and exposed bedrock are removed, and only net glacier vector data are extracted, excluding regions where the glacier terminus is unclear due to debris cover. The digitization precision of glacier boundaries is controlled within half a pixel (30m).

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the challenges faced during the manual delineation of glacier outlines from satellite images and how these challenges are addressed.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges during manual delineation of glacier outlines include the presence of snow and clouds, especially in southeastern Tibet, which can impede glacier delineation. To address these challenges, high-quality images with minimal cloud and snow coverage are selected for analysis. The manual delineation is conducted by multiple operators over several years, using false-color image composites for better ice and snow distinction. The delineated outlines undergo validation and editing at least three times by overlaying them onto Google Earth imagery, DEMs, topographic maps, and corresponding satellite images. This process involves additional glacier researchers with field survey experience to ensure accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the potential sources or strategies to enhance the quality and accuracy of glacier inventory datasets in High Mountain Asia.
Request/Directive.Answer: To enhance the quality and accuracy of glacier inventory datasets in High Mountain Asia, one strategy is to integrate multi-source data, such as high-resolution satellite imagery from different seasons, combined with topographic data like SRTM DEM. Employing a combination of automated and manual delineation methods could improve precision, especially in debris-covered areas. Utilizing a team of experts with field survey experience for validation, as well as employing advanced image processing algorithms to differentiate between ice, snow, and debris, can further refine the dataset. Continuous updates and comparisons with previous inventories could also help in tracking changes more accurately and addressing spatial and temporal variability challenges.
